results.title: Looking at Britain: trainers in training
results.creator_credit: Maxwell Munden and Max Munden Productions
results.brief_description: Training athletic coaches. To make sure there will always be enough expert instruction for the youth of Britain there are several colleges where future instructors are trained. One college is Loughborough. Here teachers of physical education are taught the techniques of different sports, learning not only to be good athletes themselves but how to pass their knowledge on to others.

results.title: Looking at Britain: British press
results.brief_description: Fleet Street is the home of three-quarters of England’s major newspapers, 16 million of which are printed every day. Shows how a newspaper gathers its news, the various functions of its staff, printing, despatch and distribution.

results.title: Looking at animals: the dog family
results.brief_description: Introduces the domestic dog as a pet, but also shows it to be a natural hunter. Includes close-ups of jaws and teeth and demonstrates speed of running and methods of swimming. Describes wild dogs of various types and shows working dogs in action.
results.description: Introduces the domestic dog as a pet, but also shows it to be a natural hunter. Includes close-ups of jaws and teeth and demonstrates speed of running and methods of swimming. Describes wild dogs of various types and shows working dogs in action.

results.title: Looking at animals: rhinos
results.creator_credit: Peter Boulton, Educational Foundation for Visual Aids and Boulton-Hawker Films
results.brief_description: A study of the “white” and “black” rhinoceroses of AFrica and the Indian rhinoceros, showing structure, physical characteristics and movement. Attention is drawn to the urgent need for the conservation and preservation of all species. The white rhino herd at Whipsnade Zoo Park is used to illustrate the role of zoos.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Peter Boulton, Educational Foundation for Visual Aids and Boulton-Hawker Films

results.title: Looking at animals: pigs and hippos
results.creator_credit: Peter Boulton, Educational Foundation for Visual Aids and Boulton-Hawker Films
results.brief_description: Illustrates the main characteristics of the related group of animals which includes pigs, peccaries and hippopotami. Draws attention to the feet and snout of pigs, and the adaptation of the hippopotamus to an amphibious life.

results.title: Looking at animals: elephants
results.creator_credit: Peter Boulton, Educational Foundation for Visual Aids and Boulton-Hawker Films
results.brief_description: A study of wild African elephants in their natural habitat. Asian elephants are then shown at work: carrying loads and, ceremoniously bedecked, taking part in an Indian festival. African and Indian elephants are compared and attention is drawn to their main points of difference.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Peter Boulton, Educational Foundation for Visual Aids and Boulton-Hawker Films

results.title: Looking at animals: cattle
results.creator_credit: Peter Boulton, Educational Foundation for Visual Aids and Boulton-Hawker Films
results.brief_description: Illustrates the wide variety of cattle: domestic breeds; including exotic varieties - draught oxen, yaks, wild bison and buffalo. Shows the easily domesticated nature of cattle, their main physical characteristics, and the process of rumination. Includes a sequence showing the birth of a calf.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Peter Boulton, Educational Foundation for Visual Aids and Boulton-Hawker Films

results.title: Looking at animals: animals with one foot
results.creator_credit: Peter Boulton, Educational Foundation for Visual Aids and Boulton-Hawker Films
results.brief_description: The appearance and characteristics of slugs and snails (gastropods) are shown. The muscular action of a common land snail in movement illustrates the meaning of the word “gastropod” (stomach-foot). Both terrestrial and aquatic snails and slugs are studied.

results.title: Looking at animals: amphibians
results.creator_credit: Peter Boulton, Educational Foundation for Visual Aids and Boulton-Hawker Films
results.brief_description: The characteristics of frogs, toads, newts and salamanders are described, compared and contrasted. To illustrate the great variety among amphibians, a European tree frog, a giant toad, an American bullfrog, a fire salamander, a muc-puppy and an axolotl are shown.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Peter Boulton, Educational Foundation for Visual Aids and Boulton-Hawker Films
